required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Tumor Growth Rate (TGR) Predicts Clinical Outcomes for Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer Undergoing Immunotherapy.
clinical_study.official_title: Tumor Growth Rate (TGR) as an Early Predictor of Clinical Outcomes in Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer Treated With PD-1 Axis Inhibitors.

collaborator.agency: Guangdong Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: We hypothesized that TGR could serve as an early predictor of outcomes for aNSCLC patients undergoing immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs). A retrospective analysis was conducted to investigate the association of TGR with response and long-term survival of aNSCLC patients undergoing ICI therapy.

detailed_description.textblock:
Tumor growth rate (TGR) signifies percentage change in tumor size per month (%/m). Electronic medical records were retrospectively reviewed for all histologically confirmed aNSCLC patients undergoing anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy at Sun Yat-Sen University Cancer Center (SYSUCC) between August 2016 and June 2018.
All response and outcome evaluation were determined as per RECIST 1.1 by two senior radiologists blinded to patients'information. Discrepancy was solved by consensus.
X-tile software was used to determine cut-off values that maximumly differentiate overall survival (OS). Log-rank tests and Cox regression models were performed for survival analysis. The predictive value of TGR for clinical outcomes in ICI-treated aNSCLC patients was validated in two external cohorts, recruited form Guangdong Province Traditional Chinese Medical Hospital and Shanghai Chest Hospital.

primary_outcome.measure: Overall survival of patients undergoing ICI monotherapy
primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of ICI treatment initiation until the date of death from any causes, assessed up to 100 months.
primary_outcome.description: Overall survival (OS) was defined as the time from immunotherapy initiation to death from any causes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Progression-free survival of patients undergoing ICI monotherapy.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From date of ICI treatment initiation until the date of first documented progression or date of death from any causes, whichever came first, assessed up to 100 months.
secondary_outcome.description: Progression-free survival was calculated from ICI initiation to radiologically-defined progression or death from any causes.

arm_group.description: Patients with low level of TGR determined by X-tile program
Patients with high level of TGR determined by X-tile program

intervention.intervention_name: This item is not applicable to our observational study.
intervention.description: This item is not applicable to our observational study.

study_pop.textblock: All histologically confirmed aNSCLC patients undergoing anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy (N = 172) at Sun Yat-Sen University Cancer Center (SYSUCC) between August 2016 and June 2018.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Histologically confirmed aNSCLC patients
- Having received anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy
- Must have two consecutive computed tomography (CT) scans upon early treatment (from baseline to the first imaging evaluation)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Lacking available computed tomography (CT) evaluation at any of two time points-baseline and the first evaluation
- Without measurable lesions at baseline CT scan
- Having received local anticancer therapy during ICI treatment, for example, radiotherapy and radiofrequency ablation

facility.name: Guangdong Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine

patient_data.ipd_description: Data including demographic characteristics, clinical information, radiological and follow-up information will be shared.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: The IPD and any additional supporting information will become available 3 months after publication.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: data can be obtained from the principal investigator by e-mail upon reasonable request.
